dc:description: The TMEM237 gene is located on chromosome 2 at 2q33.1 and encodes the transmembrane protein 237 protein. TMEM237 is a component of the transition zone in primary cilia and is required for ciliogenesis. TMEM237 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Joubert Syndrome 14 in 2011 (Huang et al., PMID 22152675). More than 10 unique variants (nonsense, frameshift, splice, missense) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least nine probands in nine publications (Boycott et al., 2011 PMID 22152675; Al-Gazali et al., 2014 PMID 27081510; Lingappa et al., 2020 PMID 32139166;  Alkuraya et al., 2012 PMID 22693042; Doherty et al., 2015 PMID 26092869; Alkuraya et al., 2016 PMID 27894351; Gunay-Aygun et al., 2017 PMID 28497568; Alkuraya et al., 2017 PMID 28600779; Hildebrandt et al., PMID 26673778). The mechanism of disease is loss of function (PMID 22152675). This gene-disease relationship is supported by expression studies, which show that TMEM237 is expressed in the ciliary transition zone, and a zebrafish model, which shows similar defects in eye and head development (Huang et al., 2011 PMID: 22152675). In summary, TMEM237 is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Joubert Syndrome 14. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

evidence.dc:description: GFP-tagged TMEM237 ortholog (named JBTS-14) concentrated to the ciliary transition zone region (specifically in the proximal regions of the cillium but just distal to the basal body).
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunofluorescence labeling

evidence.dc:description: Two polyclonal antibodies (one raised against mouse Tmem237 aa 76-88 and another against aa 390-403) were used for immunocytochemical staining of ciliated mouse inner medullary collecting duct cells and showed discrete signals consistent with localization to the ciliary transition zone.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunocytocheimcal Staining

evidence.dc:description: Should we use this evidence to upgrade variant-level evidence or score as experimental?

Immunoblot analysis of protein extract from affected individuals demonstrated constitutive phosphorylation and hyperactivation of Dishevelled-1, a core Wnt signaling protein, and
an increase in both soluble and total levels of b-catenin. Levels of downstream effectors for both canonical and noncanonical Wnt signaling, cyclin-D1 and phosphorylated myosinIIB were also assessed with immunoblot analysis. They observed a slight increase in phosphorylated myosinIIB levels and a decrease in the amount of cyclin-D1 in patient cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoblot analysis of Wnt signaling markers

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded to 1 points because although these defects could be rescued significantly by co-injection of human TMEM237 mRNA, the EP was concerned that the MOs were non-specific

Model system elucidates specific developmental effects that occur when TMEM237 is disrupted and results in similar phenotypes in zebrafish including defects in head and eye development. Zebra fish model phenotype included shortening of the anterior-posterior axis and smaller anterior structures in developing zebrafish embryos, kinking of the notochord, broadening and thinning of the somites, severe defects in head and eye development, ovoid embryonic shape suggestive of dorsalization-embryos were severely delayed in development and typically died around 10 somite age. Also displayed defects in gastrulation (as measured by length of the 5th rhombomere).
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebra Fish Model

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded because this variant is found in a consanguineous Austrian family.

evidence.rdfs:label: VIII-2
evidence.detectionMethod: A 10K Affymetric SNP array used to perform genetic mapping from one affected individual. Candidate regions identified from DNA from all 3 affected individuals and family members analyzed using dense satellite markers. Mapped to an overlapping 9.3 Mb region between D2S115 and D2S325 (Figure 1A and Figure S1B). The minimal gene-rich region (D2S115-D2S1384) contains more than 70 genes; we excluded over 30 of these by using Sanger sequencing.

member.rdfs:label: Family B-1
member.detectionMethod: Previous known loci for JSRD and MKS were excluded by homozygosity mapping. Genome-wide scan initiated with 400 polymorphic microsatellite markers. Genotyping additional affected and healthy family members refined the region to a 7.5 Mb interval between D2S2327 and D2S1384. Employed an array capture approach followed by high-throughput Roche 454 sequencing. The results from 454 sequencing were analyzed with NextGENe software. Homozygous single nucleotide variants, microinsertions, and microdeletions were called, and variants were filtered out when they were present in dbSNP132.

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded due to consanguinity
Not scored because Families A-J are all related and from the bottlenecked Hutterite population and all carry the same variant in homozygous phase.

evidence.rdfs:label: UW098-3
evidence.detectionMethod: Using Molecular Inversion Probes (MIPs),[12] all exons in genes associated with JS or the allelic disorder Meckel syndrome were captured using 100 ng of genomic DNA isolated from blood or saliva. Captured DNA was PCR amplified and sequenced on either the Illumina HiSeq or MiSeq platform. Sequence reads were mapped using the Burrows-Wheeler Aligner (BWA v.0.5.9). Variants were called using the Genome Analysis Tookit (GATK v2.5-2) and annotated with SeattleSeq (http://snp.gs.washington.edu/SeattleSeqAnnotation138/).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Individual described to have "clinical findings of JS (intellectual impairment, hypotonia, ataxia and/or oculo-motor apraxia) and diagnostic or supportive brain imaging (MTS or cerebellar vermis hyoplasia) and a "kidney only" phenotype. Desribed to have one or more of the following: increased echogenicity or cystic kidneys on ultrasound, positive kidney biopsy (microcysts, fibrosis) diagnosis of nephronophthisis, chromic renal failure, dilaysis, renal transplant

evidence.dc:description: Not scored because Families A-J are all related and from the bottlenecked Hutterite population and all carry the same variant in homozygous phase.
No specific phenotype information given but individual was described with Joubert syndrome and from a consanguineous family.

evidence.rdfs:label: MTI-131
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: no specific phenotypes listed in this review paper

evidence.dc:description: Scored default 0.1 points for a missense variant without functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 23 Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: The sequences were aligned to the human reference genome (GRCh37/hg19) using the Burrows-Wheeler Aligner program and analyzed using the Picard and Genome Analysis Toolkit (GATK)-Lite to identify variants relevant to the clinical indication. Gene annotation of the variants was performed using the Variant Effect Predictor (VEP) program against the Ensembl release 75 human gene model. Clinically relevant mutations were annotated using published variants in the literature and a set of disease databases—Clinical Variation (ClinVar), Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM), Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS), Human Gene Mutation Database (HGMD), and SwissVar. Common variants were filtered based on the allele frequency in 1000Genome Phase3, Exome Aggregation Consortium (ExAC), Exome Variant Server (EVS), Single Nucleotide Polymorphism database (dbSNP) 141, 1000 Japanese Genome, and our internal Indian population database.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: described with "pure JS" phenotype and no kidney features although authors note that renal, retinal and hepatic disease features may present later in first or second decade of life

evidence.dc:description: Not scored because Families A-J are all related and from the bottlenecked Hutterite population and all carry the same variant in homozygous phase.

evidence.dc:description: Consanguinity unknown.

evidence.rdfs:label: A374-21
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequencing was performed on an Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform after capture and amplification of 34 NPHP-RC genes in 384 affected individuals (384 families) with NPHP-RC using the Modified Molecular Inversion Probe technique. Variants with a minor allele frequency >1% were considered to be frequent SNPs and excluded. removed variants from further analysis whenever the following parameters were present: coverage < 8x, quality score < 30, and a quality by depth < 5. Variants below this threshold were considered as likely “false positives”. Furthermore, we included only missense variants that showed an evolutionary conservation down to Ciona intestinalis, a PolyPhen2-score >0.9 and a MAF <1% across the dataset. Alternatively, variants were included when they had previously been reported as disease-causing according to the HGMD®-Professional mutation database “Biobase” and were conserved down to Danio rerio. After filtering and ranking, 189 variants, including 110 potentially protein-truncating mutations (such as nonsense, frameshift, and obligatory splice site mutations), and 79 missense variants/mutations, were selected for standard Sanger sequencing.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Individuals tested for homozygous NPHP1 deletions and excluded by using a multiplex PCR-based deletion analysis.

evidence.rdfs:label: NIH Ciliopathy# 474
evidence.detectionMethod: Genotypes were called at all positions where there were high-quality sequence bases using a Bayesian algorithm called the Most Probable Genotype [Teer and Mullikin, 2010] and variants were filtered using the graphical software tool VarSifter v1.5. [Teer et al., 2012] The database dbSNP (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/snp/) covers the 1.22% of the human genome corresponding to the Consensus Conserved Domain Sequences and more than 1,000 non-coding RNAs.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Vineland-II score of 57 (An informant (parent) interview that estimates adaptive behavior and general functioning through communication, daily living, motor, and social skills. The VABC is the summary score derived from the Vineland-II), able to fix and follow, other infratentorial anomalies (not specified), EEG abnormalities (background slowing, RPQ epileptiform findings).

evidence.dc:description: RT-PCR of cDNA indicates that the splice variant led to the complete skipping of exon 9 in the mature mRNA with a predicted in-frame deletion of 64 amino acids (p.M227-R290del). Parents of proband are first cousins once removed (consanguineous family) so downgraded.

evidence.rdfs:label: JS_F4 Proband (V:2)
evidence.detectionMethod: Investigators used Affymetrix Axiom SNP Chip for genotyping. The resulting genotypes were evaluated for runs of homozygosity (ROH) using autoSNPa. In simplex cases, all ROH were considered in the search for a potential overlap with any of the previously reported JS genes. In multiplex cases, we only considered ROH that were exclusively shared by the affected members of a given family. When no candidate genes were found to overlap with the autozygome or when all autozygome-highlighted candidates were excluded by sequencing, exome sequencing was performed. TMEM237 appeared in the literature while genes were still being excluded via Sanger sequencing for sample JS_F4.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Typical MRI findings (described as having at least 2 of the following: deep posterior inderpeduncular fossa, elongated superior cerebellar peduncles, or vermin hyoplasia), Renal cysts (bilateral increased parenchymal echogenicity)

evidence.dc:description: Did not score because the authors note this is a known founder variant and a proband with this variant was already scored for the curation.
Not scored because Families A-J are all related and from the bottlenecked Hutterite population and all carry the same variant in homozygous phase.

Employed an array capture approach followed by high-throughput Roche 454 sequencing. The results from 454 sequencing were analyzed with NextGENe software.
